docs.title: 🔁 Exporting and Importing in MacroDroid
docs.text: MacroDroid provides a robust system to back up, share, and migrate your automations. You can export entire setups or specific components like macros, categories, or action blocks.

docs.title: 📦 Full Export / Import
docs.text: From the Import/Export tile on the main screen:

docs.title: Export:
docs.text:
• Export all generates a .MDR file containing:
  • All macros, action blocks, variables
  • Settings, quick tiles, drawer items
  • Choose to save to device storage or share via Android's share menu

docs.title: Import:
docs.text:
1. Tap Import/Export → Import Macros
  2. Select a .MDR file from storage
  3. Optionally reset variables on import

    Note: Resets all variables to their default values (e.g., integer → 0, boolean → false, strings → empty) when loading an .mdr file.

⚠️ Critical Warning: Importing a .MDR file will delete all existing macros and settings before restoring the imported content. This action cannot be undone.

docs.title: 🔄 Export via Action
docs.text:
Use the Export Macros action within macros:

  • To File (.MDR): Creates complete backup file
  • To Variable: Exports as JSON string Requires manual steps:
  • Save output to file
  • Rename with .MDR extension
  • Import via main screen

docs.title: Single Macro (.macro file):
docs.text:
• From macro list: Long-press macro → Export Macro
  • From editor: 3-dot menu (top-right) → Export Macro
  • Includes:
  • Triggers, actions, constraints
  • Global/local variables (if used)
  • Referenced action blocks

docs.title: Entire Category (.category file):
docs.text:
• Long-press category → Export
  • Includes:
  • All macros in category
  • Related action blocks
  • Associated variables

docs.title: Action Block (.ablock file):
docs.text:
• Action Blocks screen → Long-press block → Share
  • Contains only the action block (no macros/variables)

docs.title: 🧩 Supported Import Formats
docs.text: File Type Contents Import Method .MDR Full setup Main screen → Import Macros / Any file manager .macro Single macro + dependencies Any file manager .category Category + contents Any file manager .ablock Standalone action block Any file manager

docs.title: MacroDroid System Log Guide
docs.text: The System Log is MacroDroid's activity diary where all app events are recorded. It's essential for troubleshooting and understanding your automations. Here's what you need to know:

docs.title: 📚 What Gets Recorded
docs.text:
• Trigger activations (e.g., "WiFi connected")
  • Actions performed (e.g., "Notification sent")
  • Constraints checks (e.g., "Battery level constraint passed")
  • Variable changes (e.g., "Variable %my_var updated")
  • Errors and warnings
  • Macro start/end times

docs.title: 🔢 Log Levels Explained
docs.text:
MacroDroid categorizes entries by importance:

Level Icon What It Shows Use Case Detailed 🔍 Every single step (e.g., "Checking constraint: Time between 8:00-9:00") Deep debugging - very verbose Standard 📋 Key milestones (e.g., "Macro 'Alarm Off' triggered", "Action: Volume set to 0") Daily monitoring (recommended) Warnings ⚠️ Non-critical issues (e.g., "Location unavailable for 'Weather Update'") Potential problems review Errors ❌ Critical failures (e.g., "Action failed: File not found", "Macro disabled") Fixing broken macros

docs.title: 🔍 Filtering the Log
docs.text:
Tap the filter icon (top-right) to narrow results:

Filter by: - Event Types: - ✅ Triggers - ✅ Actions - ✅ Constraints - ✅ Variables - Macros: - Show specific macros or All Macros - Variables: - Track individual variables

docs.title: 📤 Export & Manage Options
docs.text:
Use the ⋮ menu (top-right) for:

Option Description Share Log (TXT) Export as plain text - best for sharing Share Log (HTML) Color-coded formatted report - easier to read Clear Log Wipe all entries (start fresh) Change Text Size Adjust font size (Small → Large)

docs.title: 💡 Pro Tips
docs.text:
1. Debugging: When a macro misbehaves, check the log to see where it failed
  2. Timestamp: All entries include exact execution times
  3. Color Coding: Errors (red), Warnings (orange), Actions (blue)

The log automatically scrolls to show latest entries - perfect for real-time monitoring!

Example entry: [12:30:45] 🔔 Trigger: Device Boot Completed → Macro 'Startup Setup' RUNNING [12:30:47] ✅ Action: WiFi enabled (Macro: Startup Setup) [12:30:49] ⚠️ Constraint failed: Battery > 30% (Macro: Backup Photos)

docs.title: MacroDroid User Log Guide
docs.text:
The User Log in MacroDroid is a customizable activity tracker that records only what you choose. Unlike the System Log, which captures everything behind the scenes (including system-level details), the User Log focuses purely on the events you decide to log using the Log Event action.

This makes it an ideal tool for monitoring key actions, debugging specific issues, or simply keeping a clean and relevant history of your macros.

docs.title: 📚 What Gets Recorded
docs.text:
The User Log only includes entries you’ve explicitly set up. You have full control over what’s tracked and how it's labeled.

  • Events triggered by the Log Event action (e.g., “Wi-Fi turned on”, “Sent SMS”, “Entered silent mode”)
  • Optional category tags for organization (default: General, or custom ones like “Battery Alerts”, “Location Triggers”, etc.)

Each log entry includes: - A timestamp - Your custom message - The log level you assign (explained below) - The category it belongs to

docs.title: 🔢 Log Levels Explained
docs.text:
Log levels help you prioritize, organize, and filter entries based on their importance.

Level Icon Description Best For Detailed 🔍 Fine-grained info (e.g., “Checking step X”) Step-by-step debugging Standard 📋 General activity (e.g., “Macro ran”) Day-to-day tracking Warnings ⚠️ Possible issues (e.g., “Low battery detected”) Spotting irregularities Errors ❌ Failures (e.g., “Action failed”) Identifying what broke

You can later filter logs by these levels to isolate what matters most.

docs.title: 📤 Export & Manage Options
docs.text:
From the ⋮ menu in the User Log screen, you can:

Option Description Share Log (TXT) Export as plain text for easy reading or sharing Share Log (HTML) Export a color-coded, formatted version for visual clarity Clear Log Delete all entries and start from scratch Change Text Size Choose from Small to Large for better readability

docs.title: 💡 Why Use It?
docs.text:
• Less cluttered than the System Log — only shows what’s relevant to you
  • Great for debugging — isolate a problem by adding strategic log points
  • Beginner-friendly — no technical jargon, just custom messages you define
  • Powerful for experts — can be used for precise flow analysis and behavior tracking

It’s your own custom journal for macro behavior. Use it to validate triggers, check if conditions are met, or understand what happened (and when) during macro execution.

Reference: MacroDroid User Log Documentation

docs.title: ✨ Magic Text in MacroDroid
docs.text:
Magic Text lets you inject live, dynamic data into your macros instead of static text. Think battery level, current time, sensor info, or location — values that update in real-time when your macro runs. This turns basic automations into smart, context-aware power moves.

Magic Text (trigger required) | Magic Text (no trigger needed)

docs.title: 🔹 What Is Magic Text and Where to Find It?
docs.text:
Whenever you see a "..." button next to a text field in triggers, actions, or constraints, that’s your gateway to Magic Text. Clicking it shows context-relevant options you can use.

These placeholders resolve their values the moment your macro fires, reflecting your device’s exact state.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text: A notification says: "Battery at {battery}%." When the macro runs and your battery is 42%, MacroDroid swaps {battery} for 42, so your notification reads: "Battery at 42%"

docs.title: 🔹 How Does It Work?
docs.text: Magic Text acts like a live placeholder. When the trigger fires, MacroDroid replaces it with the current value. Perfect for customizing messages or making real-time decisions.

docs.title: 🔹 Manual Use
docs.text: Know the exact code? Type Magic Text directly into any text field instead of picking from the list.

docs.title: Heads up:
docs.text:
• Syntax is everything. {battery} works, {batery} doesn’t. Typos stay literal.
  • Test before you trust. Always run your macro to confirm it resolves properly.

docs.title: 🔹 Formats
docs.text:
Two formats exist:

  • Curly brackets {}: Modern, recommended.
  • Square brackets []: Legacy, still works but less ideal.

✅ Use curly brackets whenever possible — cleaner and more reliable, especially for complex data.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text:
• {battery} → 42
  • [battery] → 42 (works, but not preferred)

docs.title: 🔹 Tips for Starters
docs.text:
• Hit the "..." button to explore Magic Text options.
  • Start small — try {battery} in a notification.
  • Test macros to make sure everything fires right.

docs.title: 🔹 Why It’s a Game-Changer
docs.text: Magic Text turns rigid automations into dynamic, real-time powerhouses. Use it to display current info, make smart decisions, and automate with real intelligence. Whether you’re just starting or a MacroDroid pro, mastering Magic Text elevates your macros to the next level.

docs.title: List
docs.text: Pagina obsoleta.

docs.title: 🧪 Does not require a trigger to operate
Am/pm
docs.text:
Magic Text: {am_pm}

Returns: am or pm depending on the current time.

Example: At 11:30 AM → returns am At 7:00 PM → returns pm

Simple explanation: Shows whether the current time is before or after noon.

docs.title: Android version
docs.text:
Magic Text: {android_version}

Returns: The Android version number of the device.

Example: If the device runs Android 13 → returns 13 If the device runs Android 11 → returns 11

Simple explanation: Shows the major Android OS version running on the device.

docs.title: Android version (sdk level)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {android_version_sdk}

Returns: The SDK level of the current Android version.

Example: Android 14 → returns 34 Android 12 → returns 31

Simple explanation: Shows the Android SDK level number for the device’s OS.

docs.title: Battery current now (ma)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {battery_current_now}

Returns: The current battery flow in milliamps (mA) at this moment.

Example: While charging → returns +800 While discharging → returns -350

Simple explanation: Shows the instantaneous current going into or out of the battery.

docs.title: Battery temp ºc
docs.text:
Magic Text: {battery_temp}

Returns: The current battery temperature in degrees Celsius.

Example: Returns 34 when the battery is at 34°C

Simple explanation: Shows how hot or cold your battery currently is in °C.

docs.title: Cell connection type
docs.text:
Magic Text: {cell_connection_type}

Returns: The current mobile data connection type (e.g., 3G, 4G, 5G).

Example: Connected to 4G → returns 4g Connected to 5G → returns 5g

Note: Can also appear as LTE, LTE (5G NSA), or other variations depending on the network.

Simple explanation: Shows your current mobile network type or generation.

docs.title: Cell id
docs.text:
Magic Text: {cell_id}

Returns: The unique ID of the cellular tower (cell) your device is currently connected to.

Example: A possible value: 3102000000 (where 310200 is the LAC)

Simple explanation: Identifies the specific cell tower your phone is using.

docs.title: Cell tower signal strength
docs.text:
Magic Text: {cell_signal_strength}

Returns: The signal strength your device receives from the nearest cell tower, measured in decibels-milliwatts (dBm). Stronger signal: around -50 dBm Weaker signal: around -110 dBm

Example: Good signal → returns -60 Weak signal → returns -105

Simple explanation: Shows how strong or weak your cellular signal is using dBm units.

docs.title: Clipboard text
docs.text:
Magic Text: {clipboard}

Returns: The current text content stored in the clipboard.

Important: Due to Android 10+ restrictions, apps cannot read clipboard content while running in the background. This action creates a temporary invisible overlay to read the clipboard content in MacroDroid. You must use the Clipboard Refresh action before using this Magic Text.

Example: If you copied "Hello World" → returns Hello World

Simple explanation: Gets the text currently stored in the clipboard, but requires a refresh action due to Android limits.

docs.title: Country code
docs.text:
Magic Text: {country_code}

Returns: The two-letter ISO country code representing the device’s current country or network region.

Example: If the device is in Mexico → returns mx If the device is in the United States → returns us

Simple explanation: Shows the country code where the device is currently located or registered.

docs.title: Create GUID
docs.text:
Magic Text: {guid}

Returns: A newly generated GUID (Globally Unique Identifier) in standard format.

Example: Returns something like 3f2504e0-4f89-11d3-9a0c-0305e82c3301

Simple explanation: Generates a unique identifier string for use in tracking or referencing.

docs.title: Current battery %
docs.text:
Magic Text: {battery} / {battery_int}

Returns: Current battery level as a percentage. {battery} returns the value with decimals (if any). {battery_int} returns the value as an integer (no decimals).

Example: Battery at 80.5% → {battery} returns 80.5 Battery at 80.5% → {battery_int} returns 80

Simple explanation: Shows the current battery percentage, with or without decimals.

docs.title: Current brightness
docs.text:
Magic Text: {current_brightness}

Returns: Current screen brightness level as a number (percentage).

Example: If brightness is set to 50% → returns 50

Simple explanation: Shows the current screen brightness as a percentage.

docs.title: Current brightness (android 9+ alternative)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {current_brightness_alternative}

Returns: Current screen brightness level as a number (percentage).

Note: This is an alternative method for devices running Android 9 and above.

Example: If brightness is set to 50% → returns 50

Simple explanation: Alternative way to get screen brightness on Android 9+ devices.

docs.title: Current ip address
docs.text:
Magic Text: {ip}

Returns: Current IP address of the device in standard IPv4 format (e.g., 172.217.12.141).

Example: Returns something like 172.217.12.141

Simple explanation: Shows the device’s current IPv4 address.

docs.title: Current ip address (v6)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {ip6}

Returns: Current IP address of the device in IPv6 format (e.g., 2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334).

Example: Returns something like 2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334

Simple explanation: Shows the device’s current IPv6 address.

docs.title: Current volume (alarm)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {vol_alarm}

Returns: Current volume level used for alarms (numeric value).

Example: If alarm volume is set to 7 → returns 7

Simple explanation: Shows the current volume level for alarms.

docs.title: Current volume (bluetooth voice)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {vol_bt_voice}

Returns: Current volume level used for multimedia and calls via Bluetooth (numeric value).

Example: If Bluetooth voice volume is set to 5 → returns 5

Simple explanation: Shows the current volume level for Bluetooth voice calls and media.

docs.title: Current volume (media / music)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {vol_music}

Returns: Current volume level used for media and music (numeric value).

Example: If media volume is set to 8 → returns 8

Simple explanation: Shows the current volume level for media and music playback.

docs.title: Current volume (notification)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {vol_notif}

Returns: Current volume level used for notification alerts (numeric value).

Example: If notification volume is set to 6 → returns 6

Simple explanation: Shows the current volume level for notification sounds.

docs.title: Current volume (ringer)
docs.text:
{vol_ring}

Returns: Current volume level used for ringtone (numeric value).

Example: If ringtone volume is set to 7 → returns 7

docs.title: Current volume (system sounds)
docs.text:
{vol_system}

Returns: Current volume level used for system sounds (numeric value). Examples include screen locking/unlocking, touch sounds, and more.

Example: If system sounds volume is set to 5 → returns 5

docs.title: Current volume (voice call)
docs.text:
{vol_call}

Returns: Current volume level during a voice call (numeric value).

Example: If call volume is set to 8 → returns 8

docs.title: Day of the month
docs.text:
{dayofmonth}

Returns: Current day of the month as a two-digit number with a leading zero for days 1 to 9. Example: Returns 04 for the 4th day, 24 for the 24th day.

docs.title: Day of the week
docs.text:
{dayofweek}

Returns: Full name of the current day of the week. Example: Returns Monday, Friday, Sunday, etc.

docs.title: Device manufacturer
docs.text:
Magic Text: {device_manufacturer}

Returns: The brand or manufacturer name of your device.

Example: Returns Samsung, OnePlus, Google, etc.

docs.title: Device model
docs.text:
Magic Text: {device_model}

Returns: The model name of your device, as reported by the system.

Example: Returns OnePlus 12 or SM-G991B depending on the device.

docs.title: Device serial
docs.text:
Magic Text: {serial}

Returns: The serial number of the device.

Example: Returns something like ABCDEF123456.

Note: On newer Android versions (Android 10+), this value may be restricted or return empty due to privacy and permission limitations.

docs.title: Device uptime
docs.text:
Magic Text: {uptime}

Returns: The duration since the device was last restarted, in hour:minute:second format.

Example: If your device has been on for 5 hours, 42 minutes, and 18 seconds → returns 05:42:18

docs.title: Device uptime (s)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {uptime_secs}

Returns: The amount of time the device has been on (since last reboot), in seconds.

Example: If your device has been running for 50 minutes → returns 3000

docs.title: Dictionary/array size
docs.text:
Magic Text: {size=}

Returns: The number of elements in an array or dictionary.

Example: If you have an array called my_array with values [0, 1, 2], then: {size=my_array} → returns 3

Note: The name after = must exactly match the array or dictionary variable you're referencing.

docs.title: Foreground app activity class
docs.text:
Magic Text: {fg_app_activity}

Returns: The activity class name of the application currently in the foreground.

Example: If MacroDroid is active → returns com.arlosoft.macrodroid.MainActivity

Simple explanation: It tells you exactly which screen or part of the app is being shown, not just the app name.

docs.title: Foreground app name
docs.text:
Magic Text: {fg_app_name}

Returns: The name of the application currently in the foreground.

Example: If MacroDroid is the active app → returns MacroDroid

Simple explanation: Shows the visible app's name — the one you're actively using at that moment.

docs.title: Foreground app package
docs.text:
Magic Text: {fg_app_package}

Returns: The package identifier of the application currently in the foreground.

Example: If MacroDroid is the active app → returns com.arlosoft.macrodroid

Usage: Can be used in any text field that supports Magic Text (e.g., logging, condition checks, notifications).

Simple explanation: Tells you which app is currently on screen, using its package name (like an app ID).

docs.title: Hour of day
docs.text:
Magic Text: {hour}

Returns: Current hour of the day in 24-hour format (00 to 23), with leading zero.

Example: At 9:30 AM → returns 09 At 3:45 PM → returns 15

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the current hour in 24-hour time, always with two digits for consistency.

docs.title: Hour of day (12h)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {hour12}

Returns: Current hour of the day in 12-hour format (1 to 12).

Example: At 9:30 AM → returns 9 At 3:45 PM → returns 3

Usage: Can be used in any text field that supports Magic Text (e.g., notifications, TTS, logs).

Simple explanation: Gives you the current hour like a regular 12-hour clock—great for friendly time formats.

docs.title: Hour of day (leading zero)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {hour_0}

Returns: Current hour of the day in 24-hour format with leading zero (00 to 23).

Example: At 9:30 AM → returns 09 At 3:45 PM → returns 15

Simple explanation: Always gives you the current hour with two digits—perfect for timestamps and logs.

docs.title: Imei
docs.text:
Magic Text: {imei}

Returns: The IMEI number of the device. ⚠️ Note: Since Android 10+, this information is no longer accessible due to privacy restrictions.

Example: Returns the IMEI number if accessible; otherwise, returns empty or unavailable.

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tries to give you the device’s IMEI, but on modern Android versions, it’s often blocked for privacy reasons.

docs.title: Language code
docs.text:
Magic Text: {language_code}

Returns: The language code currently in use. Example: English is en.

Example: Returns en for English, es for Spanish, etc.

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the two-letter code representing the language your device is using right now.

docs.title: Last known location (accuracy meters)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {last_loc_accuracy}

Returns: The accuracy (in meters) of the most recent known location. For example, it might return 10 meaning 10 meters accuracy.

Example: Returns 10 indicating the GPS location accuracy is within 10 meters.

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you how precise the last GPS location reading is, measured in meters.

docs.title: Last known location (lon)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {last_loc_long}

Returns: The longitude of the last known location.

Example: Returns -23.215252

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the longitude coordinate of the most recent location your device recorded.

docs.title: Last known location (altitude)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {last_loc_alt}

Returns: The altitude above sea level of the last known location, in meters.

Example: Returns 250 meaning the last known location is 250 meters above sea level.

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you how high above sea level your device was at its last recorded location.

docs.title: Last known location (lat)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {last_loc_lat}

Returns: The latitude of the last known location.

Example: Returns 40.7128 meaning the last known location is at latitude 40.7128.

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the latitude coordinate of the most recent location your device recorded.

docs.title: Last known location (lat,lon)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {last_loc_latlong}

Returns: The latitude and longitude of the last known location, separated by a comma.

Example: Returns 23.44325,-23.215252 meaning latitude 23.44325 and longitude -23.215252.

Simple explanation: This Magic Text provides both the latitude and longitude coordinates of your device's last recorded location in a single string.

docs.title: Last known location (link)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {last_loc_link}

Returns: A Google Maps link pointing to the last known location.

Example: Returns https://maps.google.com/?q=23.44325,-23.215252

Simple explanation: This Magic Text generates a clickable Google Maps URL showing the exact last known location of your device.

docs.title: Last known location (time)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {last_loc_age_timestamp}

Returns: The timestamp of the last known location in format year-month-day hour:minute:second.

Example: Returns 2025-05-27 14:35:22

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you exactly when your device last recorded a location update.

docs.title: Last location speed (kmh)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {last_loc_speed_kmh}

Returns: The current speed in kilometers per hour (km/h). Requires a location monitoring app like Waze or Google Maps; otherwise, the value will be 0.

Example: Returns 45 (km/h)

Simple explanation: This Magic Text shows your current speed in km/h if a compatible location app is running; otherwise, it returns zero.

docs.title: Last location speed (mph)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {last_loc_speed_mph}

Returns: The current speed in miles per hour (mph). Requires a location monitoring app like Waze or Google Maps; otherwise, the value will be 0.

Example: Returns 30 (mph)

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you how fast you’re moving in mph, but only if a compatible location app is running.

docs.title: Location area code
docs.text:
Magic Text: {lac}

Returns: The Location Area Code (LAC), a 16-bit number identifying a location area in a cellular network. Each location area contains between 1 and 65,534 radio cells.

Example: Returns 310-200

Simple explanation: This Magic Text provides the code that identifies your current location area within the mobile network.

docs.title: Macro category
docs.text:
Magic Text: {macro_category}

Returns: Name of the category of the macro that was invoked. Examples include: utilities, maps & navigation, notifications, productivity, or custom category names.

Example: For a macro in "utilities" → returns utilities

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you the category under which the triggered macro is classified.

docs.title: Macro id
docs.text:
Magic Text: {macro_id}

Returns: A GUID number uniquely identifying a macro file.

Example: 123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000

Simple explanation: This Magic Text provides a unique identifier for each macro, useful for tracking or referencing specific macros.

docs.title: Macro name
docs.text:
Magic Text: {macro_name}

Returns: The name of the macro that was invoked.

Example: If the macro is called "Morning Alarm" → returns Morning Alarm

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the exact name of the macro currently running or triggered.

docs.title: Macrodroid is pro
docs.text:
Magic Text: {macrodroid_is_pro}

Returns: Boolean value (true or false) indicating if MacroDroid is the Pro version.

Example: If you have Pro → returns true If not → returns false

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you whether you’re running the paid Pro version of MacroDroid.

docs.title: Macrodroid version
docs.text:
Magic Text: {macrodroid_version}

Returns: Version of MacroDroid installed, e.g., 5.54.x.

Example: Installed MacroDroid version → returns 5.55.0

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you the exact version number of the MacroDroid app running on your device.

docs.title: Minute
docs.text:
Magic Text: {minute}

Returns: Current minute (0–59).

Example: At 12:34 → returns 34

Simple explanation: This Magic Text shows the current minute of the hour on your device.

docs.title: Mobile country code
docs.text:
Magic Text: {mcc}

Returns: The Mobile Country Code (MCC) of the SIM card currently in the device.

Example: If the SIM is from the United States → returns 310 If the SIM is from Mexico → returns 334

Simple explanation: Identifies the country of your mobile network provider.

docs.title: Mobile network code
docs.text:
Magic Text: {mnc}

Returns: Mobile Network Code (MNC), a two or three-digit code that uniquely identifies a mobile network operator within a country.

Example: For a Telcel SIM → might return 012

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the numeric code assigned to your mobile network operator, used internally for network identification.

docs.title: Month
docs.text:
Magic Text: {month}

Returns: Current month as a number (e.g., 1 for January, 12 for December).

Example: In June → returns 6

Simple explanation: This Magic Text returns the current month number of the year.

docs.title: Month (as digit)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {month_digit}

Returns: Current month as a digit (e.g., 1 for January, 12 for December).

Example: In June → returns 6

Simple explanation: This Magic Text returns the current month number of the year.

docs.title: New line
docs.text:
Magic Text: \n

Returns: A special character that indicates the end of a line and the start of a new one. It helps organize text for better readability.

Example: Hello\nworld outputs as: Hello world

Simple explanation: This Magic Text inserts a line break, letting you split text into multiple lines.

docs.title: Power (on/off)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {power}

Returns: on or off depending on the current power state. For example, if the charger is connected, it returns on.

Example: Charger connected → returns on Charger disconnected → returns off

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you whether your device is currently charging (on) or running on battery (off).

docs.title: Ram (available)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {ram_available}

Returns: Available RAM value in GB.

Example: If your device has 2 GB free RAM → returns 2.00

Simple explanation: This Magic Text shows how much RAM is currently free and available for use on your device, measured in gigabytes.

docs.title: Ram (total)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {ram_total}

Returns: Real value of total RAM in GB (not theoretical). For example, on a device with 6 GB RAM, it might return 5.79.

Example: Device with 6 GB RAM → returns 5.79

Simple explanation: This Magic Text shows the actual usable total RAM of your device in gigabytes, which is usually slightly less than the advertised amount.

docs.title: Screen resolution
docs.text:
Magic Text: {screen_res}

Returns: Device screen resolution as width,height in pixels.

Example: For a device with 1080 pixels wide and 2400 pixels high → returns 1080,2400

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the exact screen size of your device in pixels, showing width and height separated by a comma.

docs.title: Screen resolution (x)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {screen_res_x}

Returns: Device screen width in pixels (X resolution).

Example: For a device with resolution 1080x2400 → returns 1080

Simple explanation: This Magic Text returns the horizontal pixel count (width) of your device’s screen.

docs.title: Screen resolution (y)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {screen_res_y}

Returns: Device screen height in pixels (Y resolution).

Example: For a device with resolution 1080x2400 → returns 2400

Simple explanation: This Magic Text returns the vertical pixel count (height) of your device’s screen.

docs.title: Screen timeout (seconds)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {screen_timeout}

Returns: Time in seconds before the screen automatically turns off due to inactivity.

Example: If the screen timeout is set to 30 seconds → returns 30

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you how many seconds your device waits before turning off the screen when idle.

docs.title: Second
docs.text:
Magic Text: {second}

Returns: Current second of the minute (0-59).

Example: At 12:34:45 → returns 45

Simple explanation: This Magic Text returns the current second value of the ongoing minute, from 0 to 59.

docs.title: Sim 2 operator name
docs.text:
Magic Text: {sim2_operator_name}

Returns: Name of your telephone company (SIM operator) for the second SIM slot.

Example: If your SIM 2 is from "Telcel" → returns Telcel

Simple explanation: This Magic Text shows the mobile network operator name for the SIM card in your device’s second SIM slot.

docs.title: Sim operator name
docs.text:
Magic Text: {sim_operator_name}

Returns: Name of your telephone company (SIM operator).

Example: If your SIM is from "Telcel" → returns Telcel

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the name of the mobile network operator your SIM card is currently using.

docs.title: SSID
docs.text:
Magic Text: {ssid}

Returns: The name (SSID) of the Wi-Fi network your device is currently connected to.

Example: Home_Network CoffeeShop_WiFi

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you the exact name of the Wi-Fi network your device is using right now.

docs.title: Stopwatches
docs.text:
Magic Text: {stopwatch=demo}

Returns: Total time of the stopwatch named demo in seconds (decimal format). Example: 0.0 or 195.5

Usage: Requires a stopwatch named demo to be created. Returns nothing if no stopwatch exists with that name.

docs.title: Stopwatch time (formatted)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {stopwatchtime=demo} / {stopwatchtime_no_secs=demo}

Returns: Total time of the stopwatch named demo in either hh:mm:ss or hh:mm format. Examples: - 00:00 (hh:mm) - 00:00:00 (hhss)

Simple explanation: These Magic Texts return the elapsed time of a named stopwatch in human-readable formats, with or without seconds.

docs.title: Storage free (external)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {storage_external_free}

Returns: Amount of free space available on external storage (e.g., SD card) in GB.

Example: 136GB

Simple explanation: This Magic Text shows how much free space you have left on your external storage, like an SD card, measured in gigabytes.

docs.title: Storage free (internal)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {storage_internal_free}

Returns: Amount of free space available on internal storage in GB.

Example: 136GB

Simple explanation: This Magic Text shows how much free space is left on your device's internal storage, measured in gigabytes.

docs.title: Storage total (external)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {storage_external_total}

Returns: Actual total capacity of external storage.

Example: On a theoretical 256 GB device, the real value might be: 221GB

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you the total actual capacity of your device's external storage. Real capacity is usually less than the advertised size due to formatting and system use.

docs.title: Storage total (internal)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {storage_internal_total}

Returns: Actual total capacity of internal storage.

Example: On a theoretical 256 GB device, the real value might be: 221GB

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you how much total space your device's internal storage actually has. The number may be smaller than advertised due to system formatting and reserved space.

docs.title: System setting (global)
docs.text:
Returns: A value depending on the system setting being checked. Usually, it will return 1 (enabled) or 0 (disabled).

Example: 1 (the option is enabled) 0 (the option is disabled)

Simple explanation: This Magic Text lets you check certain internal Android system settings. For example, you can use it to find out whether a specific option is turned on or off. Just replace your_setting_key_here with the name of the setting you want to check (this is called a "key").

⚠️ Important: Some system keys are sensitive. Changing them without knowing what they do can affect your device’s functionality or security. Use this only to read values—don’t try to write or modify system settings unless you know exactly what you’re doing.

docs.title: System setting (secure)
docs.text:
Returns: A value depending on the secure system setting being checked. It can be a number, text, or package name.

Example: If you use the key assistant, it might return something like: com.google.android.googlequicksearchbox/com.google.android.voiceinteraction.GsaVoiceInteractionService (This means Google Assistant is currently set as the default assistant.)

Simple explanation: This Magic Text lets you read secure Android system settings. For example, some settings store which app is used for certain features, like the voice assistant. You just replace your_setting_key_here with the name of the setting you want to read.

⚠️ Important: Secure settings control critical features of the system. Changing them without understanding their purpose can affect how your device works or compromise its security. Use this Magic Text only to read values—do not modify secure settings unless you know exactly what you're doing.

docs.title: System setting (system)
docs.text:
Returns: A value based on the system setting being checked. For time format settings, it usually returns 12 or 24.

Example: If you use the key time_12_24, it might return: 12 → The device is using the 12-hour format 24 → The device is using the 24-hour format

Simple explanation: This Magic Text allows you to check basic system preferences on the device. For example, the setting time_12_24 tells you whether the device is using a 12-hour or 24-hour clock. You just replace your_setting_key_here with the setting you want to check.

⚠️ Important: System settings control everyday behaviors of the device. While reading them is safe, changing certain values without knowing their effect might cause unexpected behavior. It’s recommended to use this Magic Text only for reading values unless you’re sure of what you're doing.

docs.title: System time
docs.text:
Magic Text: {system_time}

Returns: A number that represents the current time on the device, in Unix time (seconds since January 1, 1970, UTC).

Example: 1735689600 → This means it's exactly 00:00:00 (midnight) on January 1st, 2025 (UTC).

Simple explanation: This Magic Text shows the current time as a big number called Unix time. It counts how many seconds have passed since a fixed point in time: January 1st, 1970, at midnight (UTC). It’s commonly used by apps and systems to keep track of time.

ℹ️ Note: This number is always increasing and can be converted into a normal date/time using online tools or scripts.

docs.title: System time (ms)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {system_time_ms}

Returns: Current system time as a Unix timestamp in milliseconds.

Example: 1735689600000 → Represents 00:00:00:000 GMT on January 1st, 2025.

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the current time as a large number in milliseconds since January 1st, 1970 (UTC). It's just like {system_time}, but with three extra digits for milliseconds—great when you need more precise timing.

docs.title: Variable Length (String)
docs.text:
Magic Text: {strlen=my_var}

Returns: The number of characters in the string stored in the variable my_var.

Example: If my_var = "hello world", the result will be 11.

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you how long a piece of text is—counting all letters, numbers, spaces, and symbols in the variable.

docs.title: Variable Type
docs.text:
Magic Text: {vtype=variable_name}

Returns: A number indicating the data type of the specified variable.

Values: - 0 → Boolean (true/false) - 1 → Integer (whole number) - 2 → String (text) - 3 → Decimal (number with decimals) - 4 → Dictionary (key-value pairs) - 5 → Array (ordered list of values)

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you what kind of data a variable is storing. For example, if it returns 2, it means the variable holds a text string.

docs.title: Webhook Base URL
docs.text:
Magic Text: {webhook_url}

Returns: The base URL of your MacroDroid webhook.

Example: https://trigger.macrodroid.com/6a10aa17-75cd-4856-9d71-84281205a320/

Simple explanation: This Magic Text gives you the base part of your webhook URL. You can add your custom webhook identifier at the end to complete it.

ℹ️ Note: This is just the base URL. A full webhook URL looks like: https://trigger.macrodroid.com/6a10aa17-75cd-4856-9d71-84281205a320/mywebhook

Usage: Useful for building dynamic webhook URLs by appending the required identifier.

docs.title: Week of Year
docs.text:
Magic Text: {week_of_year}

Returns: The current week number of the year as a whole number.

Example: 1 → First week of the year 15 → Fifteenth week of the year

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you which week of the year it currently is. The year is divided into weeks starting from the first week in January. It helps track time in weeks instead of days or months.

ℹ️ Note: The exact week number can depend on local settings, but usually, the first week starts with January 1st.

docs.title: Wifi Signal Strength
docs.text:
Magic Text: {wifi_strength}

Returns: A number representing the Wi-Fi signal strength in decibels (dBm). The value is usually negative.

Example: -60 → Stronger Wi-Fi signal -70 → Weaker Wi-Fi signal

Simple explanation: This Magic Text tells you how strong your Wi-Fi connection is. The number is negative, but the closer it is to zero, the better the signal. So, -60 is a stronger signal than -70.

ℹ️ Note: A stronger signal means better connection quality and faster speeds.

docs.title: Year
docs.text:
Returns: The current year as a four-digit number.

Magic Text: {year}

Example: 2025

docs.title: App install/remove/update
docs.text:
App Name {app_name} – Returns the name of the application that was launched. Example: MacroDroid

App Package {app_package} – Returns the package name of the application that was launched. Example: com.arlosoft.macrodroid

docs.title: App Launched/Closed
docs.text:
App Name {app_name} – The name of the application that was launched or closed. Example: MacroDroid

App Package {app_package} – The package name of the application that was launched or closed. Example: com.arlosoft.macrodroid

docs.title: Bluetooth Device Connected/Disconnected
docs.text:
Bluetooth Device Name {bluetooth_device_name} – Returns the name of the Bluetooth device that was connected or disconnected. Example: Headphones 1 Pro

Requires: The macro must use the "Bluetooth device connected" or "Bluetooth device disconnected" trigger.

docs.title: Call (Active, Ended, Incoming, Missed, Outgoing)
docs.text:
Call Groups {call_groups} – Returns the name(s) of the contact group(s) associated with the caller. If the contact belongs to multiple groups, all group names are returned separated by commas. Example: Work colleagues, Friends

Caller Name {call_name} – Returns the name of the caller if available in contacts. Example: MacroDroid user

Caller Number {call_number} – Returns the phone number from which the call was received. Example: 1234567890

Requires: The macro must have a call-related trigger (Active, Ended, Incoming, Missed, or Outgoing call).

docs.title: Geofence
docs.text:
Geofence Trigger | Geofence Constraint

Geofence Name [geofence_zone_name] - Returns the name of the geofence. Example: If the geofence is named "Work Office": [geofence_zone_name] = Work Office

Geofence lat,lon [geofence_lat_lon] - Returns the latitude coordinate of the geofence's center point. Example: For a location in London: [geofence_lat_lon] = 51.5074,-0.1278

Google map link [geofence_location_link] - Returns a clickable Google Maps link to the geofence's center point. Example: [geofence_location_link] = https://maps.google.com/?q=51.5074,-0.1278

Requires: The macro must have a Geofence trigger (entry or exit) or Geofence constraint to access these Magic Text variables.

docs.title: Logcat
docs.text:
Logcat Message {logcat} – Returns the specific logcat entry line captured by the Logcat trigger in the macro. Example: 06-10 14:22:17.123 I/MyApp: Button clicked

Requires: The macro must include the Logcat message trigger configured to capture logs.

docs.title: Notifications
docs.text:
Notification Title {not_title} – The main, prominent title text summarizing the notification’s purpose. Example: New message from Josué

Ticker Text {not_ticker} – Brief scrolling text shown temporarily on the status bar (mostly obsolete since Android 5.0). Example: Josué: Hey, are you there?

Notification Content {notification} – The main body text/content of the notification. Example: Hey, I just wanted to check in.

Subtext {not_sub_text} – Secondary text that adds extra context or detail. Example: 2 new messages

Expanded Text Lines {not_text_lines} – Expanded text showing more content if the notification supports it. Example: Hey, just checking in. Let me know when you're free.

Action Button Names {not_action_names} – Names of action buttons inside the notification (like Reply, Mark as Read). Example: Reply, Mark as Read

Notification Timestamp {not_timestamp} – Unix timestamp in milliseconds indicating when the notification arrived. Example: 1735689600000

App Name {not_app_name} – Name of the app that generated the notification. Example: WhatsApp

App Package {not_app_package} – Package name of the app that created the notification. Example: com.whatsapp

Notification Channel {not_channel} – Name of the notification channel through which this notification was sent. Example: Messages

Requires: The macro must include the Notification Received trigger.

docs.title: PopUp Message
docs.text:
Popup Message Text {popup_message_text} – Returns the full text content of the popup message. Example: Low battery warning

App Name {app_name} – Name of the app that generated the popup. Example: Settings

App Package {app_package} – Package name of the app that generated the popup. Example: com.android.settings

Requires: The macro must include the PopUp Message trigger.

docs.title: SMS Received
docs.text:
Sender Name {sms_name} – Name of the sender if the number exists in your contact list. Example: MacroDroid user

Message Content {sms_message} – The content of the SMS message. Example: Hello, have a nice day

Sender Number {sms_number} – Phone number of the sender. Example: +1 1234567890

SIM Card ID {sms_sim_id} – SIM card ID that received the SMS. Example: 4

SIM Carrier Name {sms_sim_name} – Name of the mobile carrier associated with the SIM that received the SMS. Example: Vodafone

Requires: The macro must include the SMS Received trigger.

docs.title: Spotify
docs.text:
Spotify Track ID {spotify_track_id} – Returns the unique ID of the currently playing track. Example: 3n3Ppam7vgaVa1iaRUc9Lp

Spotify Artist {spotify_artist} – Returns the artist name of the currently playing track. Example: The Weeknd

Spotify Album {spotify_album} – Returns the album name of the currently playing track. Example: After Hours

Spotify Track Name {spotify_track} – Returns the name of the currently playing track. Example: Blinding Lights

Track Length (seconds) {spotify_length_s} – Returns the total length of the currently playing track in seconds. Example: 200

Is Playing {spotify_is_playing} – Returns true if music is currently playing, false otherwise. Example: true

Requires: The macro must include the Spotify trigger and the Spotify app must be installed on the device.

Possible Issues: - To ensure the Spotify trigger works, enable Device Broadcast Status in Spotify app settings. - Magic Texts won’t work without the Spotify app installed and the Spotify trigger included in the macro.

docs.title: System Log Entry
docs.text:
System Log Entry {system_log_entry} – Returns the specific text that triggered the MacroDroid system log event. Example: Battery level critical

Requires: The macro must use the System log entry trigger configured with the desired text to monitor.

docs.title: System Settings
docs.text: Provides details when a system setting is changed on the device.

docs.title: {system_setting_category}
docs.text: Returns: The category of the changed setting key. Possible values: Global, Secure, or System.

docs.title: {system_setting_key}
docs.text: Returns: The name of the setting key that was changed. Example: screen_brightness, airplane_mode_on

docs.title: {system_setting_value}
docs.text:
Returns: The new value of the setting key. Example: 1 (for enabled), 0 (for disabled), or other values depending on the key.

Requires: The macro must include the System Settings Change trigger.

docs.title: Text Shared to MacroDroid
docs.text: Provides the shared text and its subject when another app shares content to MacroDroid (e.g., selecting text in another app and using Share > MacroDroid).

docs.title: {shared_text}
docs.text: Returns: The body of the shared text. Example: Check out this cool link: https://example.com

docs.title: {shared_text_subject}
docs.text:
Returns: The subject or title of the shared content, if provided. Example: Interesting Article

Requires: The macro must include the Text Shared to MacroDroid trigger.

docs.title: Trigger that fired
docs.text:
Magic Text: {trigger_that_fired}

Returns: The name of the trigger that activated the macro.

Example: If the macro was triggered by an SMS received from any number with any content → returns SMS from Any Number (Any Content)

Simple explanation: Tells you which trigger caused the macro to run, shown as its full descriptive name.

docs.title: UI Click
docs.text: Provides access to the text that was clicked in the UI.

docs.title: {ui_click_text}
docs.text:
Returns: The text of the clicked UI element. Useful when the clicked text may vary, such as dynamic content or when using regular expressions. Example: If the clicked button says Confirm, the result will be Confirm.

Requires: The macro must include the UI Click trigger.

docs.title: USB Device Connected
docs.text: These magic text values are available when a USB device is connected.

docs.title: {usb_product_name}
docs.text: Returns: The name of the connected USB device. Example: SanDisk Ultra USB 3.0

docs.title: {usb_manufacturer_name}
docs.text: Returns: The manufacturer of the connected USB device. Example: SanDisk

docs.title: {usb_device_hash}
docs.text:
Returns: A unique identifier (hash code) generated for the connected USB device. Useful for identifying and differentiating USB devices. Note: This hash may vary depending on the port or device state.

Requires: The macro must include the USB Device Connected/Disconnected trigger.

docs.title: Weather
docs.text:
Magic Text: {weather_temperature_c} Returns: Current temperature in degrees Celsius. Example: Returns 22 if the temperature is 22°C Simple explanation: Shows the current temperature in °C.

Magic Text: {weather_temperature_fahrenheit} Returns: Current temperature in degrees Fahrenheit. Example: Returns 71.6 if the temperature is 71.6°F Simple explanation: Shows the current temperature in °F.

Magic Text: {weather_wind_speed} Returns: Current wind speed in meters per second (m/s). Example: Returns 3.5 if wind speed is 3.5 m/s Simple explanation: Shows how fast the wind is blowing in m/s.

Magic Text: {weather_wind_speed_mph} Returns: Current wind speed in miles per hour (mph). Example: Returns 7.8 if wind speed is 7.8 mph Simple explanation: Wind speed shown in mph.

Magic Text: {weather_wind_speed_kmh} Returns: Current wind speed in kilometers per hour (km/h). Example: Returns 12.6 if wind speed is 12.6 km/h Simple explanation: Wind speed shown in km/h.

Magic Text: {weather_wind_direction} Returns: Wind direction in degrees (0–360). Example: Returns 270 if the wind is coming from the west Simple explanation: Shows wind direction as an angle (e.g., 90 = east).

Magic Text: {weather_humidity} Returns: Current humidity percentage. Example: Returns 60 if the humidity is 60% Simple explanation: Shows how humid the air is right now.

Magic Text: {weather_conditions} Returns: Text description of the current weather conditions (e.g., "clear sky", "rain", "overcast"). Example: Returns clear sky Simple explanation: Describes the weather in plain words.

Requires: You must use the Weather trigger before accessing these Magic Texts.

docs.title: ⏱️ Stopwatches in MacroDroid
docs.text: Stopwatches allow you to measure elapsed time inside your macros — perfect for tracking durations, delays, or custom time-based logic.

docs.title: 📍 Where to Find Stopwatches
docs.text:
You can access and manage stopwatches from the Stopwatch tile on the main screen of MacroDroid. From there, you can:

  • ➕ Create new stopwatches
  • ✏️ Rename existing stopwatches
  • 🗑️ Delete stopwatches you no longer need
  • ▶️ Start/Stop any stopwatch manually

📺 Video Tutorial: Watch the official MacroDroid stopwatch guide here: 👉 MacroDroid Stopwatch YouTube Video

docs.title: 🧩 Using Stopwatches in Macros
docs.text: Stopwatches can be integrated into different parts of your macros:

docs.title: 🔫 Trigger
docs.text: Trigger a macro based on stopwatch conditions 👉 Introduction to triggers 👉 Stopwatch trigger

docs.title: 🎬 Action
docs.text: Start, stop, reset, or get the current time from a stopwatch 👉 Introduction to actions 👉 Stopwatch action

docs.title: 🚧 Constraint/Condition
docs.text: Run actions only if a stopwatch has passed or not passed a set duration 👉 Introduction to constraints 👉 Stopwatch constraint

docs.title: ✨ Magic Text
docs.text: Use stopwatch values dynamically in text fields (e.g., notifications, logs) 👉 Magic text introduction 👉 Magic text stopwatch

docs.title: 🛠️ Common Use Cases
docs.text:
• Measure how long since an event happened
  • Delay actions until a stopwatch exceeds a time
  • Reset time after specific conditions
  • Log or display how much time passed between two points

Think of stopwatches as custom timers you control — start them when something begins, stop them when it ends, and use that info to make smart decisions inside your macros.

docs.title: 🚀 Introduction to Triggers in MacroDroid
docs.text:
Triggers in MacroDroid are instantaneous events that your device detects to start a macro. They are the spark that initiates your automation, telling MacroDroid when to execute the macro’s actions. From detecting a screen unlock to receiving a notification, triggers allow you to create responsive and dynamic automations tailored to your needs.

Go to trigger list

docs.title: 🔹 What Are Triggers?
docs.text: A trigger is an event that your device can detect, such as a change in battery level, a specific time, or a location update. For a macro to be valid, it must include at least one trigger. The macro must also be enabled (not disabled) at the exact moment the trigger event occurs for it to fire.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text: A trigger like "Charger Connected" can start a macro that runs actions such as "Turn On Wi-Fi" or "Show Notification" when you plug in your device.

docs.title: 🔹 Using Multiple Triggers
docs.text: You can add multiple triggers to a single macro. If any one of these triggers fires, the macro will execute, assuming all constraints (if any) are met. This provides flexibility to start a macro from different events.

docs.title: Important Note:
docs.text: Triggers cannot be combined with AND logic (e.g., "Trigger 1 AND Trigger 2") using a "Trigger Fired" constraint because triggers are instantaneous events. It’s highly improbable for two events to occur at exactly the same time. When a macro runs, it is always initiated by exactly one trigger.

docs.title: Alternative to AND Logic:
docs.text: Instead of combining triggers with AND, you can add constraints to individual triggers to limit when they fire based on other conditions. For example, you can add a "Time of Day" constraint to a "Screen On" trigger to ensure it only activates during specific hours.

docs.title: Example:
docs.text: A macro with two triggers—"Charger Connected" and "Headphones Connected"—will run its actions if either event occurs. To make a trigger like "Charger Connected" only fire during the day, add a constraint like "Time of Day: 8:00 AM - 10:00 PM" to that specific trigger.

docs.title: 🔹 Common Trigger Examples
docs.text: MacroDroid offers a wide variety of triggers to suit different automation needs. Some popular examples include: - Device Events: "Screen On/Off," "Charger Connected/Disconnected," or "Battery Level Drops." - Time-Based: "Regular Interval" (e.g., every hour) or "Specific Time." - Connectivity: "Wi-Fi Connected/Disconnected" or "Bluetooth Device Connected." - Notifications: "Notification Received" from a specific app. - Location: "Enter/Exit Location" based on GPS or network data.

docs.title: 🔹 Why Are Triggers Important?
docs.text:
• Initiation: Triggers are the starting point of every macro, determining when your automation runs.
  • Flexibility: With multiple triggers, you can make a single macro respond to various events.
  • Precision: Adding constraints to triggers allows you to fine-tune when they activate, ensuring your macros run only in the right context.

docs.title: Practical Example:
docs.text:
A macro designed to save battery might include: - Trigger: "Battery Level Drops Below 20%" to detect low battery. - Additional Trigger: "Screen On" to catch when the device is actively used. - Constraint (on the "Screen On" trigger): "Not Charging" to ensure the macro only runs when the device isn’t plugged in. - Actions: "Lower Brightness" and "Show Notification: Low Battery!"

Triggers are the foundation of MacroDroid’s automations, giving you control over when your macros run. Whether you’re creating simple automations or complex workflows with multiple triggers and constraints, experimenting with triggers will help you unlock the full power of MacroDroid!

docs.title: Accessibility Service Changed
docs.text:
Description: This trigger fires when an accessibility service is enabled or disabled. It can be configured to monitor one or more specific applications.

Example: Trigger an alert when the accessibility service is disable to remind the user to configure settings.

Simple explanation: This trigger detects changes in the status of accessibility services, allowing you to automate actions based on whether such services are turned on or off.

docs.title: Activity Recognition
docs.text:
Description: Activates when your device detects a specific physical activity such as driving, cycling, running, walking, or standing still.

Configuration: - Activity type: Select from In Vehicle, On Bicycle, Running, Walking, or Still. - Confidence value (0–100): Determines the detection threshold. - Lower values trigger more often but might be inaccurate. - Higher values are more precise but may miss some detections.

Requires: Google Play Services must be installed and up to date.

Example: Trigger when the user starts running with at least 80% confidence.

Example 2: When activity is detected as In Vehicle with 90% confidence, automatically enable Do Not Disturb mode — restricted to trigger only between 7 AM and 10 PM.

Simple explanation: This trigger fires automatically when your phone recognizes you're doing a certain physical activity, like walking or driving. You can pair it with specific actions and limit it to certain times or conditions to avoid false positives.

docs.title: Airplane Mode Changed
docs.text:
Description: Activates when airplane mode is turned on or off.

Example: Trigger when airplane mode is turned off to automatically re-enable Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.

Simple explanation: This trigger detects changes in airplane mode status, allowing you to automate actions when connectivity is disabled or restored.

docs.title: App Activity Launched/Closed
docs.text:
Description: This trigger fires when a specific app activity is launched or closed. You can choose to activate it on open or close events.

Configuration: - Activation type: Choose whether to trigger on activity launch or close.

  • Activity name matching options:

  • Matches: Exact match of the activity name. Example: com.example.MainActivity matches only that exact activity.

  • Contains: Triggers if the activity name contains the specified text anywhere. Example: Settings matches com.android.SettingsActivity or SettingsFragment.

  • Wildcards support:

  • * matches any sequence of characters.

  • ? matches any single character. Examples:

    • com.example.* matches all activities starting with com.example.
    • MainAct?vity matches MainActivity and MainActXvity.

  • Regular expressions: Enable with "Enable regular expression matching" option. Use regex patterns for more flexible matching. Example: com\.example\.(Main|Settings)Activity matches either com.example.MainActivity or com.example.SettingsActivity.

  • Case insensitive: Optionally ignore case differences when matching. Example: settings matches SettingsActivity or settingsactivity.

Example: Trigger when com.example.MainActivity is launched to start a timer.

Simple explanation: This trigger detects when an app screen opens or closes. You can use exact names, partial matches, wildcards, or regex to precisely specify which activities activate your automation.

docs.title: App Install/Remove/Update
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates when an app is installed, removed, or updated on your device. You can choose to trigger for any app or select one or more specific apps from a list.

Configuration: - App selection: Choose to trigger on any app or select Select Application(s).

  • Event type: Select which event(s) to monitor: Install, Remove, and/or Update.

Magic Text: This trigger supports Magic Text variables to use app-related info in actions. App install/remove/update

Example: Trigger a notification when WhatsApp is updated.

Simple explanation: Automate actions based on app lifecycle events—installations, removals, or updates—either globally or limited to apps you care about.

docs.title: Application Launched/Closed
docs.text:
Description: This trigger fires when an application is opened (launched) or closed. You can target one or more specific apps using the app list or define the target by package name.

Configuration: - App selection: - Select one or more apps from the list, - Or enter the package name manually. Example: com.instagram.android refers to the Instagram app.

  • Trigger type: Choose whether to trigger when the app is launched or closed.

  • Force legacy mechanism:

  • If enabled, MacroDroid will use an older detection method.

  • Useful if the new implementation doesn’t work on your device or you don’t want to grant Accessibility access. Example: On older Android versions or restricted OEMs (e.g., Xiaomi/MIUI), the default method might not detect launches correctly. Enabling legacy mode may fix this.

  • Magic Text: You can insert Magic Text using the ... button when defining the package name. App Launched/Closed

Example: Trigger when com.spotify.music is launched to increase media volume.

Simple explanation: This trigger detects when a specific app opens or closes, either by selecting it from a list or by entering its internal name (package). Legacy mode helps on phones where the normal detection doesn’t work properly.

docs.title: Auto Rotate Changed
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates when the system's auto-rotate setting is turned enabled or disabled.

Configuration: - State: Choose between Enabled or Disabled to determine when the trigger should fire.

Example: Trigger a toast message when auto-rotate is disabled.

Simple explanation: Fires when you toggle the auto-rotate setting on or off—great for adapting behavior based on screen orientation control.

docs.title: Autosync Changed
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates when the system-wide auto-sync setting is turned enabled or disabled.

Configuration: - State: Choose between Enabled or Disabled to determine when the trigger should activate.

Example: Trigger a notification when auto-sync is enabled to inform that data will now sync in the background.

Simple explanation: Fires when the global sync setting is toggled—useful for responding to changes in background data behavior.

docs.title: Battery Level
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates based on changes in the battery level. You can choose whether to trigger when the level increases, decreases, or changes in any direction.

Configuration: - Trigger type: - Decrease to: Fires when battery drops to the specified percentage. - Increase to: Fires when battery rises to the specified percentage. - Any change: Fires on any battery level change.

Magic Text:

Current battery Battery temperature c Battery current now mA

Note: These Magic Text variables are available globally, even if this trigger is not used.

Example: Trigger low-power mode when battery decreases to 20%.

Simple explanation: Fires when your battery reaches a specific percentage or simply changes. Great for optimizing behavior based on battery status.

docs.title: Battery Saver State
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates when the system's battery saver mode is turned on (enabled) or off (disabled).

Configuration: - State: Choose whether the trigger fires when battery saver is Enabled or Disabled.

Magic Text:

Current battery Battery temperature c Battery current now mA

Note: These Magic Text variables are available globally, even if this trigger is not used.

Example: Activate dark mode when battery saver is enabled.

Simple explanation: Fires automatically when your device enters or exits battery saver mode, allowing you to adapt your automations to low-power scenarios.

docs.title: Battery Temperature
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates based on changes in the battery temperature. You can choose whether to trigger when the temperature increases, decreases, or changes in any direction.

Configuration: - Trigger type: - Decrease to: Fires when battery temperature drops to the specified value (°C). - Increase to: Fires when battery temperature rises to the specified value (°C). - Any change: Fires on any change in battery temperature.

Magic Text:

Current battery Battery temperature c Battery current now mA

Note: These Magic Text variables are available globally, even if this trigger is not used.

Example: Trigger a cooling alert when battery temperature increases to 45°C.

Simple explanation: Fires when your device’s battery temperature reaches a specific point or changes, allowing you to take action before overheating becomes a problem.

docs.title: Bluetooth Event
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates based on changes in your device's Bluetooth status or when a Bluetooth device connects or disconnects.

Configuration: - Event type: - Bluetooth enabled: Fires when Bluetooth is turned on. - Bluetooth disabled: Fires when Bluetooth is turned off. - Device connected: Fires when a Bluetooth device connects. - Device disconnected: Fires when a Bluetooth device disconnects.

  • Device selection (for connected/disconnected): You can choose Any device or select a specific previously paired device from the list.

Magic Text:

Bluetooth

Note: Magic Text values are available when using the Device connected or Device disconnected options.

Example: Launch the music app when your car’s Bluetooth connects.

Simple explanation: Fires when Bluetooth is toggled on/off, or when a device connects/disconnects — ideal for automating tasks around headphones, cars, or other Bluetooth accessories.

docs.title: Bluetooth Beacon
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates when a specified Bluetooth beacon comes into range or goes out of range of your device.

Configuration: - Trigger type: - Beacon in range: Fires when the selected beacon is detected nearby. - Beacon out of range: Fires when the selected beacon is no longer detected.

  • Beacon selection:
  • Beacons can be detected automatically by scanning.
  • If a beacon is not found during scan, it can be added manually by entering its Beacon UUID and an Beacon name.

Example: Start a timer when a specific beacon comes into range (e.g., entering the car).

Simple explanation: Fires when your device detects or loses connection to a specific Bluetooth beacon. Useful for proximity-based automations.

docs.title: Device Boot
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates when the device finishes booting and the user unlocks the device for the first time after startup.

Example: Turn on Wi-Fi automatically after the device restarts and is unlocked.

Simple explanation: Fires once after the phone turns on and is unlocked — useful for setting up initial tasks after a reboot.

docs.title: Calendar Event
docs.text:
Description: This trigger activates when a calendar event starts or ends. You can customize it to respond only to certain events, calendars, or event details.

Configuration:

  • Trigger type: Choose whether the trigger fires when an event starts or ends.

  • Calendar account: Select which calendar to monitor. Examples:

  • Local device calendar
  • Specific email calendar like mymail@example.com

  • Special calendars like Holidays in Mexico or Family

  • Availability filter: Filters events based on their status:

  • Free: Events where you are marked as free (no busy status)
  • Busy: Events where you are marked as busy (e.g., meetings)

  • Any: All events regardless of availability

  • Event matching by title or details: You can limit triggering to events whose title or details match certain patterns.

  • Wildcards:
    • * matches any number of characters
    • ? matches exactly one character
    • Example:
    • Meeting* matches Meeting with John or Meeting123
    • Lunch? matches Lunch1 but not Lunch12
  • Regular Expressions (regex):
    • More powerful, flexible pattern matching. Enable with the option "Enable regular expression matching".
    • Example regex:
    • ^Call\s\d{3}$ matches exactly Call 123 but not Call1234 or Call 12

  • Case insensitive:

    • When enabled, matching ignores uppercase/lowercase differences.
    • So meeting matches Meeting and MEETING.

  • Ignore all-day events: Skip events that last all day, which often are reminders or holidays.

  • Use alarm: Instead of triggering exactly at event start or end, this option triggers when the calendar alarm goes off for the event.

  • Check in advance: Set how early or late the trigger fires relative to the event time. Use days, hours, and minutes.

  • Positive values mean trigger before the event.
  • Negative values mean trigger after the event.
  • Examples:
    • Trigger 15 minutes before a meeting: set 0 days, 0 hours, 15 minutes
    • Trigger 10 minutes after event ends: set 0 days, 0 hours, -10 minutes

Magic Text:

Calendar event details

Example: Trigger a reminder 10 minutes before any busy event with a title starting with Doctor (e.g., Doctor appointment) in your mymail@example.com calendar.

Simple explanation: This trigger helps you automatically act when events start or end. It’s flexible: you pick which calendar, event status, and even match event titles or details using easy wildcards or advanced regex patterns.

docs.title: 📍 Trigger: Geofence (location)
docs.text:
Geofence triggers automatically start your macros when your device enters or exits a defined geographical area. They provide battery-efficient location detection using Google Play Services.

Geofence Constraint | Magic Text

docs.title: Activation Type
docs.text:
• Entry: Triggers when device enters the geofenced area
  • Exit: Triggers when device leaves the geofenced area

docs.title: Trigger if previous location unknown
docs.text: • Trigger if previous location unknown: When enabled, the trigger will activate even if the device's previous location wasn't known. Useful for: Ensuring triggers fire after device reboot or when location services were temporarily disabled.

docs.title: 🔹 Update Frequency Settings
docs.text:
High frequency update rates may cause additional battery drain.

Requires: - An existing geofence created via the Geofences tile - Location services enabled on device - Google Play Services

docs.title: 🧠 Understanding Variables in MacroDroid
docs.text: Variables are used to store and manipulate data in your macros — they’re like containers that hold values your macros can use and modify as they run.

docs.title: 🔄 Types of Variables
docs.text: MacroDroid supports two main types of variables:

docs.title: 🌐 Global Variables
docs.text:
• Syntax: {v=varName} or [v=varName]
  • Scope: Available in all macros, including Action Blocks
  • Ideal for sharing data between different macros or across multiple triggers

docs.title: 📦 Local Variables
docs.text:
• Syntax: {lv=varName} or [lv=varName]
  • Scope: Only available within the macro where they were created (including Action Blocks called by that macro)
  • Ideal for temporary or macro-specific values

Use Global Variables when you need persistent or shared data. Use Local Variables for isolated, one-time-use values within a single macro execution.

docs.title: 🧰 Supported Variable Types
docs.text:
You can create variables using different data types depending on your needs:

  • String – Text (e.g. "Hello world")
  • Integer – Whole numbers (e.g. 5, -12)
  • Decimal – Numbers with decimals (e.g. 3.14, -0.01)
  • Boolean – True/False
  • Array – A list of values (e.g. [1, 2, 3] or ["A", "B", "C"])
  • Dictionary – A collection of key-value pairs (e.g. {"name": "Alex", "age": 30})

These types allow for powerful data handling inside your macros.

docs.title: 🔒 Secure Variables
docs.text:
When creating a variable, you can choose to mark it as Secure.

A variable marked as secure will have its contents cleared when macro(s) are shared/exported or uploaded to the template store.

This is useful when your variable holds sensitive information like passwords, tokens, or personal data that shouldn’t be shared.

docs.title: ⚙️ Variables in Conditions and Constraints
docs.text:
Variables can be used in:

  • Conditions (e.g., “if isLoggedIn is true”)
  • Constraints (e.g., “run only if batteryLevel > 50”)
  • Text fields by referencing {v=yourVar} or {lv=yourVar}
  • Magic Text inputs across actions

They let you dynamically control the behavior of your macros based on real-time values.

docs.title: 💡 Summary
docs.text:
Type Syntax Scope Good For Global {v=varName} All macros and action blocks Shared or persistent data Local {lv=varName} Single macro and its blocks Temporary or isolated values Secure (any variable) Same as global/local Hiding sensitive data in exports

Variables are the brain of your macro logic. Master them and you’ll unlock the full power of MacroDroid 🚀
